ï»¿Execution Version Dated October 9, 2014 COLLABORATION ARRANGEMENT relating to Global In rastructure Facility Partnership Program
ï»¿Execution Version This Collaboration Arrangement is en:ered into on October 9, 2014 between: (1) THE GOVERNMENT OF CA 4ADA ACTING THROUGH THE DEPARTMENT OF FORE G N AFFAIRS, TRADE AND DE% ELOPMENT, HEREIN REPRESENTED BY THE MINISTER F C' INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT, headquartered at Gatineau, QC, Canada (the "Gove 'r r,ent of Canada"); and (2) THE WORLD BANK GROUF, comprising the INTERNATIONAL BANK FOR RECONSTRUCTION AND DEVELOPMENT ("IBRD") and INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPIh EN f ASSOCIATION ("IDA"), heac quartered at 1818 H Street, NW, Washington, DC 20433, Us, , : le INTERNATIONAL FINANCE CORPORATION, ("IFC") headquartered at 2121 Pennsylvar ik Avenue, NW, Washington, Dt 20433, USA, and the MULTILATERAL INVESTMENT GUARANTEE AGENCY, ("MIGA"), headquartered at 1818 H Street, NW, Washington, D( C 1133, USA (the "World Bank Group") (each a "Signatory" and together, the "Signatories"). Preamble (A) There is broad internationa recognition, as confirmed by the G20, the OECD, Inter It nal Organizations (lOs), the G77 and the private sector represented by the B20 that investinj in the infrastructure of Emerging IVarkets and Developing Economies (EMDEs) is needed, to aq: ind access to basic services an( raise living standards for all, and to meet global economic r: /vth targets. (B) Meeting this need presents a significant financing challenge. Given constraints on Ji ing sources of infrastructure finaice-particularly in the public sector-a redoubled and cooi:1ir, ted effort is needed to mobilize p ivate sector finance for EMDE infrastructure. (C) There is an absence of robLst pipelines of structurally sound and bankable projects ani :l's is understood to be the greates barrier to achieving significantly more infrastructure investm it (D) Governments, development i nance institutions, donors, and private investors share an in set in developing the market for pr vate infrastructure finance in EMDEs: both on the demand s di , in the numbers of structurally s(,und and bankable projects seeking finance, and gradual emir;: ice of EMDE infrastructure as a recognized asset class; and the supply side, in the range oi pr ate investors that actively partic pate in financing those projects. Achieving these goals will IE efit from collective action betwe in this range of entities-to leverage resources and knowl fl( ! to find solutions to complex iifrastructure financing challenges that no single institutio c uld achieve alone. (E) In support of these goals, tre Signatories propose the establishment of a Global Irfras:r.i(: ure Facility Partnership Program ("GIF"). The GIF will be an open global platform aiming at le: -E ing the efforts of the wide range of institutions currently engaged in supporting EMDE infras:r.: ure with the participation of private infrastructure investors, coalescing around project prep :E on, structuring, and risk mitigation for individual infrastructure investments. In this regard, re 31F aims to complement existin(I and proposed services and initiatives currently supportec :" the Signatories and other prospective GIF partners. The GIF intends to provide resources to :> E are well-structured, infrastructur projects, and to serve as an additional mechanism for ac::en ing the expertise of the Signatories and other GIF partners, in combination with guidan :( -om prospective private sector fiianciers into project structures. The GIF thereby aims to 1:h ave greater leverage of official resources in the face of substantial EMDE infrastructure nE s:: -in particular for large and comp ex projects with the potential to attract significant private cap 1 I (F) The Signatories are now inte-ested in collaborating in developing the Global Infrastructure I'z ility Partnership Program, togethier with other partners. 1
ï»¿Execution Version Accordingly, the Signatories have t:ome to the following understanding: 1 Global Infrastructure Facility Partnership Program Framework 1.1 The GIF is intended tb be based on the preliminary objectives and principles set o it ii Annex 1 (Preliminary GIF Foundational Principles). The Signatories acknowledge their mu Ia understanding that while the 31F Foundational Principles are an initial basis for their collal c r ion, they are of an indicative natu e and will continue to be developed amongst the Signatories ri with other potential partners t ntil the GIF is formally established. The final version of these objectives and principles will >e agreed upon by the GIF Partners and be reflected in tie agreement establishing the C IF. 1.2 The Signatories interd to work together with any additional participants who may t, collaborating on the GIF to fu ther enhance their coordination, in particular by developing t i IF, with a view to formally establishing the program by December 2014. 2 Further Collaboration 2.1 Pursuant to the foreg oing, the Signatories will use reasonable endeavors to contin .H collaborate in developing the GIF, including but not limited to: a. Nature and scope of :ollaboration under the GIF, such as proposed categories of partnership and the r)les, rights, and responsibilities associated with each categoi , b. Governance arrange nents of the GIF; c. Operational policies ipplicable to the GIF's operations; d. Scope of GIF activitiE s and sources/uses of GIF funds, including approach to proj( cI selection criteria and coordination with the Signatories' existing facilities; and e. Any other aspects of collaboration required to finalize the design of the GIF, incluc r g sharing best practice and experience with regard to project preparation, through t1 tL e of knowledge platforris for the infrastructure sector. 2.2 During the process of finalii ing the design of the GIF, the multilateral development banl E I ted in Annex 2 will be invited to participate as initial Technical Partners. Once the G[F d i- i is finalized, additional collaborative efforts are required to develop the operational details 1: the GIF, at all times complem nting existing efforts and facilities and building upon the red knowledge and experience )f the Signatories in this area. This includes determining the i I of coordination between the Signatories and project origination process. 3 General 3.1 This Collaboration At rangement is not a legally binding agreement or commitment ty he Signatories to enter into or piovide support for any specific activity or project. The Signato !5E acknowledge that the provisions of this Collaboration Arrangement represent their commo 1 understanding and intentions only and that the Signatories do not intend to create or impo :o iy legal obligations or liabilities an any Signatory. 3.2 This Collaboration A rangement is valid and effective for a period of one year fron h date thereof, unless superse led at an earlier date by the establishment of the GIF. 3.3 The Signatories expect that this document and information with respect to the collaborative activities contemplated herein will be publicly disclosed. Such disclosure will as made in accordance with the Signatories' respective disclosure policies. The Signatories I ir o 2
ï»¿Execution Version consult with each other concE(rning the manner and form of any acknowledgment of the ot i( r Signatory's support regardinc the activities. 3.4 Nothing in this arrant ement will constitute or be construed as a waiver, renunciati,r other modification of any of ft e privileges, immunities and exemptions granted to any of th Signatories under their const tuent documents, international conventions and any applicab,z 1: NS In witness whereof, each of the Sigr atories has caused this Collaboration Arrangement to be exE ci d in two (2) counterparts of equal content and form by a duly authorized representative of each Sign, it : as of the date first set forth above. 3

ï»¿Execution Version THE WORLD BANK GROUP, compr sing the INTERNATIONAL BANK FOR RECONSTRUCTIO1 H A ID DEVELOPMENT, the INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT ASSOCIATION, the INTERNATIONAL FINANCE CORPORATION and the MULTILATERAL INVESTMENT GUARANTEE AGENCY By: YON KIM, PRESIDEN- 5
ï»¿Execution Version Annex I Preliminary GIF Foundational Principles 1 Objectives 1.1 The objective of the GIF is to promote private sector investment in infrastructure pc jE ts in emerging markets and developing economies (EMDEs) through robust project preparati:)i, provision of appropriate risk r nitigation instruments, and thereby increasing the commercia ir i institutional investor engagement in the EMDE infrastructure market. It is focused on collaboration in complex pubf c-private partnerships and projects with potential for commei:: a viability which require project preparation resources, policy dialogue and eventual infrastru:' u i financing solutions that no sir gle institution could achieve alone. 1.2 To this end, the GIF aims to create a global platform to provide financial and coorc ir E on resources in collaboration witi the project preparation, advisory, and financing efforts of th A Je range of donor and developrr ent finance institutions currently engaged in supporting EMD E infrastructure, with the input z nd ideas of private infrastructure investors. GIF's engagemei t c uld stretch from upstream support on project definition, preparation, and investment feasibility assessment, through to dowr stream transaction preparation, financial structuring, and risk mitigation/credit enhancemer t. 1.3 Over the longer term by contributing to the stock of high quality and well-structure: infrastructure projects, the GIF can be expected to help in the development of EMDE infrastructure as an asset cla 5s attractive to a wide range of private investors seeking long t: i assets in faster growing ecoromies, but which until now have been presented only limited infrastructure investment opportunities that meet their risk tolerance and investment profile 2 Operating Principles 2.1 The GIF intends to ooerate according to the following core principles, to be finalizE c )on agreement among GIF partnors: (i) Leveraging the arivate sector-specializing in project financing modalities U I ill draw together co'nparative advantages of public and private sectors; (ii) Addressing put lic goods-focusing on core infrastructure; particularly thosE infrastructure prcjects that are climate friendly or trade enabling; (iii) Promoting sust iinability and inclusiveness-ensuring projects adhere to t e practice standarc s for social and environmental responsibility; and (iv) Collaborating, complementing and partnering for solutions-mobilizing t( c- cal and financial resources of all partner entities-World Bank Group entities, mu :i a: ral development ins itutions, other public institutions, and private investors-in ar innovative and floxible way, to complement existing capacities, achieve greatE r leverage and address the complex infrastructure financing challenges that are beyond the resources of any individual partner. 3 Institutional Arrangements and Governance 3.1 The GIF is expected to involve a wide range of stakeholders who are involved in t w development and implementation of infrastructure projects, both public and private. GIF p, r ni rs are expected to fall into one or more of the following categories: 6
ï»¿Execution Version (i) Funding Partneis-Partners that provide financial contributions to the GIF wi I :1: considered Fund ng Partners. (ii) Technical Partn ars-Partners that can and who will agree to provide specific technical advice ind support to GIF activities including execution of GIF-funde:1 activities and/or F rovision of GIF-backed credit enhancement or liquidity suppc r instruments. (iii) Advisory Partners-Private investors or entities that represent the voice of commercial and/or institutional investment, whether pension funds, insurance companies, sove eign wealth funds, banks or other financial institutions, as w( II,= other multilateral or bilateral agencies engaged in supporting private sector infrastructure pro ects, to be invited into discussions related to project prepara ik r optimal approaches to financial structuring, and the design and use of risk instruments, with a view to ensure suitability of projects for commercial and/or institutional investment. 3.2 A GIF Governing Cc uncil is proposed to oversee the GIF's strategic programmin1 management and use of funds, and development of operational policies and procedures; e 1:1 hold the GIF Management Ur it (see section 4.1) accountable for delivering on the facility's objectives and principles, witt advice and support from the Advisory Partners. The cornpo! iic of the Governing Council will be agreed between IBRD and prospective partners, but is prop( se: to comprise representatives of F unding and Technical Partners. 3.3 An Advisory Councl comprised of all GIF partners, chaired by the Managing Dir( zck and Chief Financial Officer of the World Bank Group, will be periodically convened to facilil aE coordination of GIF activities 3nd support GIF operations. This Advisory Council will serve :i sounding board, providing gu dance and support for GIF Management, and in particular wi re view to ensuring suitability of projects for private sector investment. 4 Management 4.1 The GIF will be admi iistered by the World Bank Group, through a small, dedicate( e: m established for this purpose (:he GIF Management Unit). The GIF Management Unit will fu 1:i >n as a coordinating body as prcjects are identified for inclusion in the pipeline, and then mov : toward technical support and financing phases. The GIF Management Unit will not lead in( i: al projects. 4.2 GIF activity implementation teams will be led by selected staff of Technical Partne institutions, coordinated by the GIF Management Unit in consultation with client governme i; according to specific project requirements and the project origination processes. Compos :i n of the implementation teams m; iy vary according to the need of individual projects and govem nr nts. 5 Activities and Projects 5.1 Project selection cr teria and processes could be developed to reflect the follov iiI principles: (i) Development Inipact-projects that support the development goals of the GI partner institutior s; (ii) Alignment-pro ects that are aligned with recipient/sponsor country priorities :it: strategies; (iii) Complexity-pr jects that require multiple parties to come together to providi structuring, arrarging and financial support, and/or projects which require a bl i!t of financial instrum)nts; and 7
ï»¿Execution Version (iv) Catalytic Impac -projects that have significant potential to achieve financial / a: lity, leverage public funds, and attract private sector and/or institutional investors- s. 1 1 as through Public -Private Partnership (PPP) modalities-while still meeting government's sei vice delivery objectives. The GIF will focus on infrastructure investments that have global public good characteristics ich as climate friendly-project. that are low emitting or encourage efficiency in the provisior cf infrastructure services; and tiade enabling-projects that facilitate or enhance interconne t v y and trade. 5.2 The scope of support provided to a particular project will be defined flexibly, with a3 ' w to complementing the resources and support already available from partner entities and ot iir funding mechanisms. During :he GIF pilot phase, this support may include the following ac:ii: as, corresponding to major project development stages: (i) Project definition and enabling environment - sector planning and investment prioritization; pro ect definition, including needs analysis and pre-feasibility scr :(r 1g; and legal, regula ory, or institutional reforms; (ii) Project preparation and investment feasibility - feasibility studies, investment appraisal, and PPP structuring; (iii) Transaction supp ort and financial structuring - preparing and implementing transactions, anc design of risk mitigation/credit enhancement packages; and (iv) Financial arrangi ig and credit enhancement - arranging and mobilizing financi packages from a range of sources and partners. 6 Operational Policies Sound operational policies-iicluding in particular the management of environmental and :Uc 3l impacts and risks, and transparency in procurement-are critical to the success of infrastri cl:c. e projects in supporting sustainable, inclusive development; as well as for investors in those projects to manage financial, reputational and legal risks. In developing the appropriate framework for GIF-supported operations, the GIF could draw upon existing arrangements a external implementing entitie:; under World Bank Partnership Programs. GIF partners will collaborate to establish an approach to fiduciary, environmental and social safeguards anc t ar standards and policies, and cevelop, manage and oversee an accreditation process for Gl Technical Partners who are expected to function as implementing entities for GIF activitieE 8
